author: By Ann Carrns
title: A ‘Glitch’ in Federal Health Insurance May Soon Be Fixed
description: Federal rules make it hard for relatives of people with job-based coverage to qualify for financial help in buying Obamacare insurance. The Biden administration wants to change that.
content: A “family glitch” sounds like a minor mix-up, like missing dinner. But when talking about health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, it means a costly loophole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: This Time, D. Wayne Lukas Is Riding Into the Preakness on a Filly
description: The 86-year-old trainer has saddled 45 horses in the race during his long career. Will Secret Oath give him his seventh Preakness and 15th Triple Crown victory?
content: BALTIMORE — D. Wayne Lukas knows his fillies. He won the 1988 Kentucky Derby with Winning Colors and made champions out of Lady’s Secret, Serena’s Song, Althea and Life’s Magic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: 6 Audiobooks to Listen to Now
description: This month’s recommendations feature Viola Davis, a supernatural World War II horror novel and a steamy Jamaican romance.
content: From the sexy to the searing, the metaphysical to the unabashedly depraved, horror to high camp, these recent audiobooks in a variety of genres are hard to turn off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Loftus
title: When an Abortion Is Pro-Life
description: If God does not want us to perform abortions, why did he put me in a situation where I would have to do one?
content: This guest essay contains graphic descriptions of a doctor performing an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Selam Gebrekidan, Matt Apuzzo, Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
title: Invade Haiti, Wall Street Urged. The U.S. Obliged.
description: The long occupation of Haiti began with a drumbeat from the bank that became Citigroup, decades of diplomatic correspondence and other records show.
content: In the drowsy hours of a December afternoon, eight American Marines strolled into the headquarters of Haiti’s national bank and walked out with $500,000 in gold, packed in wooden boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kuttner
title: Democrats, the Midterm Jinx Is Not Inevitable
description: Standard political history may not be a good guide to 2022.
content: In November, the Democrats are widely expected to lose the House and probably also the Senate. Large defeats are the norm for a new president’s first midterm. A harbinger is a president’s approval rating, and President Biden’s stands at a lackluster 41.1 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith and Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden’s Curious Talking Point: Lower Deficits Offer Inflation Relief
description: The administration says federal spending trends are helping rein in price increases, but the economic calculus may be more complicated.
content: As Americans deal with the highest inflation in decades, President Biden has declared that combating rising costs is a priority for his administration. Lately, he has cited one policy in particular as an inflation-fighting tool: shrinking the nation’s budget deficit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A Hat Tip to 4 New Picture Books
description: Three off-the-top-of-the-head stories and a piece of fitting history.
content: THE UPSIDE DOWN HATBy Stephen BarrIllustrated by Gracey Zhang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: On Race, Herschel Walker’s Offer of Absolution Divides Georgia Voters
description: Georgia will still have a Black senator next year, but the likely Republican nominee, Herschel Walker, and the incumbent Democrat, Raphael Warnock, offer far different visions on race.
content: MACON, Ga. — Herschel Walker, the former football star leading Georgia’s Republican primary for Senate, had a mixed message about racial issues for 70 or so supporters, mainly white, who came to hear his stump speech this week at the Georgia Sports Hall of Fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon don’t quite spoil the ending.
content: ACROSTIC — I'm pretty sure that most solvers of Cox/Rathvon acrostics are conditioned to scan the entries at the start, to see what kind of theme jumps out. I certainly do, every time, and I often find myself falling for a clever red herring (happily, no ego here). Today, for example, religious references jumped out immediately: “Spirit connected with Pentecost,” “Eastern mystic,” “Insect whose name means ‘prophet,’” “Form of black magic; mojo.” These made me envision some sort of sacred text as the source of today’s passage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Spring Auction Sales for Two Blockbuster Weeks Top $2.5 Billion
description: Eleven auction records for artists — six by women — were smashed on Thursday night in two sales at Sotheby’s.
content: Two blockbuster weeks of marquee evening sales ended in Manhattan on Thursday night with doubleheader Sotheby’s auctions of rising stars and established contemporary names that raised a combined $283.4 million — and smashed 11 records for artists, including six by women. This pushed the running total for various spring sales at Sotheby’s, Christie’s and Phillips to more than $2.5 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Chelsea Daniel, Diana Nguyen, Stella Tan, Paige Cowett, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A Better Understanding of Long Covid
description: Who does the condition affect, and how widespread is it?
content: Throughout the pandemic, long Covid — symptoms that occur after the initial coronavirus infection — has remained something of a medical mystery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Palestinian Poetry to Stories on Reproductive Freedom
description: A selection of books published this week; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: PEEP, by Danielle Blau. (Waywiser, paper, $17.) The winsome, intellectually probing poems in Blau’s debut collection examine lived experience through the lens of myth, memory and rigorous philosophical inquiry, with one eye on the instant when, “at this moment’s close, you’ll cross the border / into the moment after. … Your shadow’s growing shorter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Constant Méheut, Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo
title: The Ransom: A Look Under the Hood
description: Thousands of pages of original documents, and hundreds of books and articles. Here are the historians and researchers on which the Haiti project drew.
content: This series was the work of four reporters and more than a dozen researchers. Over the course of more than a year, we examined thousands of pages of original documents found in public and private archives and libraries, mainly in Haiti, the United States and France. We also read hundreds of books and articles, from tomes published shortly after the Haitian revolution began in 1791 to the most recent, which arrived in bookstores in France just months ago. We cannot cite them all. But we do want to offer readers an idea of how we researched this series and came to the conclusions we did, as well as to give credit to historians and researchers whose work formed essential building blocks for our stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Sacred or Sexist? After a Brazen Theft, Seeing de Kooning in a New Light.
description: When “Woman-Ochre” goes on view at the Getty Museum after its conservation, the painting will have a new mystique. But competing interpretations remain.
content: LOS ANGELES — Ulrich Birkmaier’s job as senior paintings conservator at the Getty Museum involves painstakingly repairing aging canvases and removing botched varnishes or restorations so artworks can return in full health to public view. He is by profession pretty much the opposite of an art thief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dickson
title: Combing the Beach, and the Archives, to Revive ‘The Wreckers’
description: In the early 20th century, Smyth was probably the most famous female composer of her generation, but her music fell out of the repertoire. Glyndebourne Festival Opera is bringing back her 1906 maritime opera.
content: LEWES, England — Late last fall, there was an unusual sight on a beach in southern England: a team of staff members from Glyndebourne Festival Opera combing the shingle for flotsam and jetsam, then carting it off in wheelbarrows for use onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: What Does It Mean to Live in Ukraine? Filmmakers Offer Their Answers.
description: Some, like Sergei Loznitsa, choose to use history as a filter. But the movies that stand out forgo monumental statements for personal ones.
content: When Russia invaded Ukraine in February, my social media feeds filled with denunciations of Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, and listicles recommending how best to support Ukraine. This all made me feel a bit sheepish. Suddenly, Ukrainian cinema was relevant, and a familiar, woozy feeling returned: What use is any of this against the blunt reality of war? What might be achieved by engaging with Ukrainian art and film beyond the flaccid goal of raising awareness?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Hustles to Recruit Soldiers and Halts Gas Supplies to Finland
description: The war has evolved into something of a stalemate that has seriously depleted Russia’s conventional war capabilities, even as it has made some gains.
content: BERLIN — Russia took new steps on Friday to gird for an escalating struggle with the West over the war in Ukraine, moving to expand military recruitment to older citizens and severing gas supplies to Finland in apparent retaliation for its Nordic neighbor’s application to join the NATO alliance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Halfway Around the World, Their Paths Finally Crossed
description: Sope Ogundipe’s mother had prayed he would one day marry a Nigerian woman. That day came after meeting Iyanu Imoru at a computing conference in San Diego.
content: Mosopefoluwa Ogundipe and Iyanuoluwa Imoru are from the same Nigerian state, Ondo, the same local government area, Akoko North-East, and the same Yoruba tribe. But it wasn’t until they were halfway around the world that their paths finally crossed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Catching Feelings, and the Flu
description: Wanting to end their first date on a romantic note, Dr. Shilpen Patel leaned in for a kiss with Yuming Chiu, who did not mention he was a little sick.
content: As so often happens on a first date, Yuming Albert Chiu shared more than he ought to have on the night he met Dr. Shilpen Ajit Patel for dinner, in San Mateo, Calif., in February 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Girl, 11, Was Killed When One Teen Tried to Shoot Another, Police Say
description: The police filed charges in a Bronx slaying that came as New York’s children are suffering in a wave of violence.
content: The killing in the Bronx was a crime committed among the young.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on Smudging the Cabinets
description: A married couple has a disagreement about grubby hands.
content: Andrew writes: Our kitchen cabinets are off-white. My wife recently asked me to make sure I touch only the handles when I open them to cut down on smudges. I find this absurd. I use the cabinets dozens of times a day: I can’t account for where my fingers land. Do I lie and promise to try, knowing that I will not change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Suzi Gablik, Art Critic Who Took Modernism to Task, Dies at 87
description: As a collage artist and reviewer, she was an it-girl of avant-garde art. But she turned on that world in 1984 with her salvo of a book, “Has Modernism Failed?”
content: Suzi Gablik, an art critic, author and theorist who once championed modernism — and was once an artist of that persuasion — but found fame when she turned against it, died on May 7 at a hospice facility in Blacksburg, Va. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx and Katherine Schulten
title: How Educators Around the World Are Teaching the Russia-Ukraine War
description: Via both Times articles and ideas from readers, here is a look at how classrooms of all kinds are grappling with the war and its effects.
content: Please note: This is a special Lesson of the Day that brings together many different sources and ideas. Unlike our usual format, this is written to teachers, not students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: On Ukraine, McConnell Tries to Show the World This Isn’t Trump’s G.O.P.
description: The top Senate Republican traveled to Europe in a bid to show that isolationism hasn’t taken over his party. He has privately lobbied his colleagues to vote that way, and so far, most are.
content: WASHINGTON — When former President Donald J. Trump came out against the $40 billion military and humanitarian aid package for Ukraine, casting it as a misguided act of charity, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky feared the Republican votes against the bill could pile up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Shipstead
title: Elif Batuman’s Alter Ego Goes Back to College. Her Minor: Overthinking.
description: In the follow-up to “The Idiot,” the protagonist returns to Harvard for another year of exquisite intellectual torment and underwhelming romance.
content: EITHER/ORBy Elif Batuman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an action-noir, a South African story of rebellion against apartheid and more.
content: A good action-noir can excavate the darker corners of humanity while delivering the pleasures of the genre. That happens with “Brut Force,” from the writer-director Eve Symington. It stars Lelia Symington (the director’s sister) as Sloane Sawyer, a whip smart investigative reporter who owes much to the gumshoes of noir past, in a drama concerning fractured families and deadly secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Lyon’s Women Bridge Eras in a Changing Champions League
description: The arrival of new money in women’s soccer has come at a cost in Europe: It has separated the sport from its past.
content: They have gone, one by one, not so much swept aside as barged out of the way. Umea, the Swedish team that first brought Marta to Europe, the superpower that appeared in the first three finals of what would become the women’s Champions League, ran first into financial ruin and then, as night follows day, sporting disrepair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: America Almost Took a Different Path Toward Abortion Rights
description: Roe v. Wade was never expected to be the case that made history.
content: For three days in January 1970, they filled the 13th floor of the federal courthouse in Manhattan, women of all ages crowded into a conference room, sitting on the floor, spilling into the hallway. Some brought friends or husbands. One nursed a baby. Another was a painter who also taught elementary school. A third had gone to Catholic school. They’d come to give testimony in the case of Abramowicz v. Lefkowitz, the first in the country to challenge a state’s strict abortion law on behalf of women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: C.D.C. Urges Adults 50 and Older to Get Second Booster Shot
description: Previously, the agency said those 50 and older could opt for the additional shot, but encouraged only people over 65 or with underlying medical conditions to get it.
content: WASHINGTON — In a sign of growing concern among federal health officials about the spread of new coronavirus infections, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is now saying that all people 50 or older should get a second booster shot if at least four months have passed since their first booster dose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Spot the greenwashing
description: Corporate climate pledges are everywhere. Some are solid, others definitely are not.
content: There are a lot of corporate climate pledges out there, and it’s easy to be cynical about them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: The Met’s ‘Akhnaten’ Takes a Post-Grammys Victory Lap
description: Philip Glass’s portrait of a pathbreaking pharaoh returns to the Metropolitan Opera for the first time since its hit debut there in 2019.
content: It wasn’t so long ago this season — just January — that the Metropolitan Opera’s programming was about as classic as it gets: tried-and-true works by Verdi, Puccini and Mozart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Bonding Over a Love of Cat Power and Senior Dogs
description: Michael Grassi and Matthew McConkey quickly connected over their favorite musician and deepened their relationship through a mutual fondness for older dogs.
content: Matthew Thomas McConkey was at home watching the movie “Death Becomes Her” when he first spotted Michael Grassi on the dating app Grindr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam
title: Trump’s Out of Office, but the MAGA Merchandise Machine Keeps Chugging
description: President Biden’s recent criticism of “ultra-MAGA” Republicans has led to a new business opportunity for entrepreneurial conservatives.
content: Denouncing “ultra-MAGA” Republicans in a recent speech about fighting inflation, President Biden clearly saw an opportunity to tie the party to Donald Trump and the far-right fringe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Russia’s Fallout with Finland
description: Moscow will cut natural gas supplies to its Nordic neighbor this weekend.
content: Good evening. I’m the new writer of the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Warhol Museum Reimagines the Factory in a New ‘Pop District’
description: The museum aims to create an arts and music destination in Pittsburgh, teach skills to young people and shore up its finances.
content: A “Pop District” is being planned in Pittsburgh, the Pop artist Andy Warhol’s hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R.O. Kwon
title: An Ode to Living With, and Despite, Pain and Mortality
description: In Akwaeke Emezi’s latest novel, “You Made a Fool of Death With Your Beauty,” a young widow stumbles into new life and romance while grieving for her past love.
content: Every now and then, in my more low-spirited moments, I find myself suspecting that I know of no country more ill equipped for grieving, no society less capable of making space for the depths and complexities of life-changing sorrow, than the United States. Whether or not everyone would agree with that suspicion, the United States, along with the rest of the world, is living through a time of more loss than usual, and for some grievers, myself included, mourning hasn’t occurred in tidily named stages, nor has it meaningfully eased with time. It is entirely possible to continue grieving for what is gone for years, decades, a lifetime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Brooklyn Street Named for Robert E. Lee Now Honors Black War Hero
description: A street on New York City’s only Army base was renamed in honor of First Lt. John Earl Warren Jr., a Brooklynite who died saving others in Vietnam.
content: A main street inside New York City’s only Army post now bears the name of a Black officer who died saving others in Vietnam — instead of the name of the Confederate general who led the South’s attempt at secession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: The Allegations Against Musk
description: Musk has denied claims of sexual misconduct against an employee, saying that Insider wrote the story to interfere with his acquisition of Twitter.
content: The news site Insider dropped a set of explosive allegations about Elon Musk last night. It reported that a former flight attendant on a SpaceX corporate jet accused Musk of harassment. Insider cited interviews and documents it had obtained to back up its reporting. (The New York Times has not independently confirmed the reporting.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Hungary’s thirst for Russian oil.
content: Prime Minister Viktor Orban says the E.U.’s proposed embargo on Russian oil would devastate his country’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: A former ‘Power Rangers’ actor is charged with helping steal millions in Covid relief funds.
description: Jason Lawrence Geiger, known professionally as Austin St. John, made false claims to obtain money from the Paycheck Protection Program, prosecutors said.
content: The actor who led a team of teenage superheroes on “Mighty Morphin Power Rangers” has been accused of helping steal millions of dollars from the government’s Paycheck Protection Program pandemic relief fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney
title: 6 Takeaways About Haiti’s Reparations to France
description: How did the modern world’s most successful slave revolt give birth to a desperately poor nation? Here is a summary of what a team of New York Times correspondents found out.
content: A failed state. An aid trap. A land seemingly cursed by nature and human nature alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: What Parents Need to Know About Sharing Breast Milk
description: More families are informally swapping milk during the baby formula shortage. But experts warn there are risks.
content: Margie Smith has always produced much more breast milk than her children need. When her son was born three years ago, Ms. Smith — who pumps exclusively — was making more than 50 ounces of breast milk per day, “enough to feed twins at least,” she said. With her 10-month-old daughter, she is producing less, but still more than her baby can drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Who Referees the Referees? On TV, He Does.
description: Steve Javie was an N.B.A. official for 25 years. Now he spends his time on TV during games, telling viewers if today’s refs are making the right calls.
content: SECAUCUS, N.J. — “They think they know refereeing,” Steve Javie muttered to no one in particular, wearing a wry smile. “It’s even hard in slow motion.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Brian Morton on ‘Tasha: A Son’s Memoir’
description: Morton discusses his first work of nonfiction, and Rachel Careau talks about translating “Chéri” and “The End of Chéri,” by Colette.
content: Brian Morton, an accomplished novelist, has turned to nonfiction for the first time in his new book, “Tasha: A Son’s Memoir.” On this week’s podcast, he discusses his mother’s life, the difficulties in taking care of her toward the end of her life and what led him to write a  memoir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Some Abortion Opponents Make Economic Arguments. They’re In for a Fight.
description: A legal brief by 154 economists says overturning Roe v. Wade would financially harm women.
content: If you believe abortion is murder, its economic consequences are beside the point. Morality trumps all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Peter Baker
title: In South Korea, Biden Seeks to Rebuild Economic Ties Across Asia
description: The president plans to unveil a new regional economic framework, but some in the region wonder whether it will be an empty exercise.
content: PYEONGTAEK, South Korea — When President Biden arrived on his inaugural mission to Asia on Friday, the first place he headed from the airplane was not a government hall or embassy or even a military base, but a sprawling superconductor factory that represented the real battleground of a 21st-century struggle for influence in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Renowned Gullah Geechee Cook Gets Her Own Book and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Girlhood’ and ‘The World Without Us’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: GIRLHOOD: Essays, by Melissa Febos. (Bloomsbury, 336 pp., $18.) Febos’s eight essays on growing up in a female body — and how it is irrevocably marked by patriarchy — draw on investigative reporting, memoir and scholarship to create a “feminist testament to survival” in a voice that is “irreverent and original,” our reviewer, Betsy Bonner, commented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Harry Styles Is Still a Dreamy Cipher on His Third LP, ‘Harry’s House’
description: The title of the pop star’s latest album suggests open-door intimacy, but instead pairs more vivid sonic landscapes with less revealing lyrics.
content: On “Harry’s House,” the third solo album from the colossally charismatic former member of the British boy band One Direction, 28-year-old Harry Styles often sings from a perspective that is a combination of a prematurely wise elder, a personal cheerleader and a pro bono therapist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Pentagon Press Secretary Named to White House Communications Post
description: John Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, will focus on national security and work alongside the new White House press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon press secretary, John F. Kirby, the voluble public face of the Defense Department for the past year and a half, is moving to the White House in a new role as President Biden’s national security voice, the White House announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: I Was Late to the Walter Mosley Party. Now I’m an Evangelist for His Work.
description: His expression of Black English — and Black thought — is brilliant.
content: About 20 years ago, I gave a talk at a bookstore on race issues. Afterward, a white woman on the staff approached me warily and gave me a novel by Walter Mosley. She told me, with a worried, sympathetic smile, that she thought I should read it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: As Seen in Chemistry Class
description: Hal Moore concocts an interesting puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When I’m solving a puzzle filled with interesting entries, I look forward to seeing how many of them are debuts, which are words and phrases appearing in the New York Times Crossword for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: What’s the Best Way to Find a Gifted 4-Year-Old?
description: New York City has abandoned its test to screen for gifted and talented children. Now the responsibility of choosing students falls squarely on teacher recommendations.
content: How can you tell if a preschooler is gifted? In the late 1990s, researchers at the Center for Gifted Development in Colorado approached the question by asking parents of older children who were deemed intellectually advanced what sort of characteristics manifested themselves early on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: A Weak Euro Heads to an Uncomfortable Milestone: Parity With the Dollar
description: The euro hasn’t fallen below the one-to-one exchange rate with the U.S. dollar for two decades. But as economic risks grow, more analysts predict deeper lows for the shared currency.
content: The list of ailments troubling the eurozone economy was already stark: the highest inflation rate on record, energy insecurity and increasing whispers about a recession. This month, another threat emerged. The weakening euro has raised expectations that it could reach parity with the U.S. dollar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Jessie Buckley Take a Haunting Tunnel Walk in ‘Men’
description: The writer and director Alex Garland narrates a sequence from his film.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Truth About Waist Trainers
description: Some claim the corset-like garments help wearers slim their midsections. Here’s what the experts say.
content: Corsets are back. In reality, they never left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla’s Aura Dims as Its Plunging Stock Highlights the Risks It Faces
description: Production problems in China and Elon Musk’s pursuit of Twitter are leading investors to wonder whether the electric car company is worth as much as they thought.
content: Investors are reassessing the premise that justified Tesla’s astronomical stock price and made its founder, Elon Musk, the richest person in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kate Greasley
description: A conversation with the abortion ethicist.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kate Greasley. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: In Georgia, a G.O.P. Primary Tests the Power of a Trump Vendetta
description: Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger is fending off a challenger fueled by Donald J. Trump’s election lies. But do voters still care about 2020 as much as the former president does?
content: ATLANTA — An anti-Trump Republican advocacy group recently organized a focus group of G.O.P voters in Georgia to get their take on perhaps the most competitive and consequential primary election in the state. They heard a lot of indecision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Attack ads have fueled sharp ups and downs in the Alabama G.O.P. Senate race.
description: Deep-pocketed outside groups have spent freely to disparage the rivals of their preferred candidates.
content: The three leaders of Alabama’s Republican Senate race have experienced giddy ascents and, in some cases, steep plunges, with the result that Representative Mo Brooks and two first-time candidates, Katie Britt and Mike Durant, enter Tuesday’s primary election tightly bunched together in recent polling. Unless one tops 50 percent, which seems unlikely, there will be a runoff between the top two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Free Ambulances in Mogadishu, Thanks to This Determined Dentist
description: Dismayed that victims of the incessant violence in Somalia’s capital were being rolled to hospitals on wooden carts and in wheelbarrows, a dentist decided to do something about it.
content: MOGADISHU, Somalia — On the way to and from his dental clinic every day, Dr. Abdulkadir Abdirahman Adan was appalled by an all-too-common sight: severely injured and dead Somalis being transported to hospitals in wooden hand carts or wheelbarrows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Open Houses and Sticky Fingers
description: Real estate agents warn that open houses can sometimes turn into magic shows — personal items just disappear. “Kleptomania is a real condition,” one agent said.
content: When my grandmother passed away in 1981, my mother, the executor of her estate, oversaw the selling of her one-bedroom apartment on 72nd Street and Third Avenue. Doyle, the New York-based appraising company, assessed her furnishings, and her personal and sentimental belongings were removed. All that remained was her furniture and my mother’s beautiful satin A-line wedding dress, which was left hanging in the coat closet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: S&P 500 Drops for Seventh Straight Week but Evades Bear Market
description: Investors are selling as they worry about inflation, interest rates and a potential recession.
content: A chaotic day on Wall Street extended the longest period of market turmoil since 2001, with stocks on Friday briefly descending into bear market territory, a symbolic marker of investors’ deep pessimism about the health of the global economy and the buying power of the American consumer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A New Kind of Drug
description: How the country’s drug problem is changing, and why it’s growing.
content: For much of human history, people got their drugs from nature. Marijuana comes from the cannabis plant, cocaine from coca leaves, heroin from poppies and magic mushrooms really do come from mushrooms. Even legal drugs, like alcohol, tobacco and coffee, come from plants. Their highs were often discovered by chance, when someone consumed them in just the right way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Karine Jean-Pierre’s Unlikely Rise to the White House Lectern
description: The first Black and first openly gay press secretary was raised in an immigrant family with “so many secrets.” Now she occupies one of the most scrutinized jobs in American politics.
content: Karine Jean-Pierre began her debut briefing as President Biden’s press secretary on Monday by acknowledging the unusual nature of her presence behind the White House lectern. “I am a Black, gay, immigrant woman, the first of all three of those to hold this position,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Alexandra Stevenson
title: As China Doubles Down on Lockdowns, Some Chinese Seek an Exit
description: Inquiries to immigration consultants have surged; social media users trade tips on how to get abroad. But the government aims to “strictly restrict nonessential exit activities.”
content: Clara Xie had long wondered whether she might leave China one day. She chafed at the country’s censorship regime, and as a lesbian, she wanted to live in a country more accepting of same-sex relationships. Still, the idea felt distant — she was young, and didn’t even know which country she would choose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Barkhorn
title: A Pro-Life Doctor on Performing a Lifesaving Abortion
description: “If God does not want us to perform abortions, why did he put me in a situation where I would have to do one?”
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Officials Report a Possible Monkeypox Case in New York
description: The patient is under care at Bellevue Hospital while further testing is conducted.
content: Days after unusual clusters of the rare monkeypox virus emerged in Europe, New York City health authorities announced on Thursday that they were investigating a possible case of the rare disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Rina Sawayama Flips Damnation Into a Dance Party, and 15 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Burna Boy, Metric, Sudan Archives and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut, Catherine Porter, Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo
title: Demanding Reparations, and Ending Up in Exile
description: A firebrand Haitian president tried to hold France to account for its years of exploitation. He soon found himself ousted from power.
content: The shock came midway through the speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Should I Do About a Friend’s Racist Figurines?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to deal with a friend who won’t give up their offensive knickknacks.
content: I have been friends for years with someone on the opposite end of the political spectrum. He is conservative, and I am liberal. I try to understand where he is coming from, though we differ on many issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Capturing the Anarchy in the Sex Pistols
description: ‘Pistol,’ a new mini-series directed by Danny Boyle, is based on a memoir by the punk band’s bassist and founder, Steve Jones.
content: LONDON — “Are we doing any spitting?” asked a man in the crowd at the 100 Club, a small, red-walled underground space, redolent of spilled beer, cigarette smoke and a thousand lost nights, just off London’s Oxford Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Vangelis, Composer Best Known for ‘Chariots of Fire,’ Dies at 79
description: A master of the synthesizer, he won an Oscar for that film’s score, and his memorable theme song became a No. 1 pop hit.
content: Vangelis, the Greek film composer and synthesizer virtuoso whose soaring music for “Chariots of Fire,” the 1981 movie about two British runners in the 1924 Summer Olympics in Paris, won the Academy Award for best original score, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: A Room in Midtown Is Quietly Fighting the Battle Against City Noise
description: A new room in Manhattan, billed as ‘one of the quietest in the world,’ is designed to help developers and architects defend your ears.
content: People like to tell me all the ways that New York is too loud. They send emails to my Ask Real Estate column complaining about the noises that torment them during the day and keep them up at night. There are the usual suspects — barking dogs, crying babies, outdoor diners, jackhammers and sirens. But even seemingly pleasant sounds — wind chimes, children playing, opera singing — can induce rage, given the right circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Louis Vuitton Meets Nike in Virgil Abloh’s Dream Sneaker
description: The Air Force 1, manufactured in Italy, will be unveiled in a new installation in Brooklyn. It was one of the designer’s final projects before his death.
content: Over the years, Virgil Abloh approached his work with Nike as something slightly different than a straightforward collaborator. He was a tinkerer. A nudger. A questioner. Often his ideas verged on the raw: What if you punch holes in the sneaker? What can we print on it? What if we rendered the invisible parts of construction visible?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Priceless Sculptures Are ‘Literally Being Chipped Away’
description: More than 1,000 terra-cotta sculptures — of firefighters, mermaids, steelworkers — adorn the walls of Parkchester in the Bronx. Is there a plan to protect them?
content: Among the more than 33,000 residents of Parkchester, the sprawling 1940s Bronx apartment complex, the most exuberant characters tend to hang out at the buildings’ entrances and corners: folk singers and firefighters, accordion players and harlequins, steelworkers and mermaids. There are exotic fauna as well, not typically found in such urban environs: gazelles, puffins, kangaroos and bears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: White House Press Secretary Gets a New ‘Flak Jacket’: A Women’s Blazer
description: A decades-long West Wing tradition lives on, with a bright yellow twist.
content: By longstanding, bipartisan tradition, decades of White House press secretaries have handed down a cheeky symbol of their job fielding rat-a-tat inquiries from feisty reporters: a flak jacket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy Says Ancient Statue in U.S. Museum Was Stolen, Not Lost at Sea
description: A court near Pompeii has ordered the return of a treasured classical antiquity that was purchased by the Minneapolis Institute of Art almost four decades ago.
content: TORRE ANNUNZIATA, Italy — The account has long been that a shipwreck in the ancient past had sent a precious Roman marble statue — a rare copy of a fifth century B.C. depiction of the “Doryphoros,” or spear bearer — into the depths of the seas off Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Should I Steer Clear of Fast Fashion?
description: A reader asks for advice on shopping ethically and affordably.
content: In 2015, one of the first documentaries on fast fashion’s impact on the planet was released. Directed by Andrew Morgan, it was titled “The True Cost.” The implication was, of course, that it would reveal the real price the earth is paying for our embrace of overconsumption when it comes to clothes. It did do that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: C.D.C.’s Pandemic Team Will Surrender Some Responsibilities
description: The transition was announced in a letter to agency employees, but details were scant.
content: Just weeks after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention began a comprehensive internal review with an eye toward restructuring, the agency’s director announced on Friday that the team that coordinated the national response to the Covid-19 pandemic would return some of its functions to other departments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood’s Last Real Movie Star
description: At a time when superheroes dominate the box office, the film industry hopes the actor can bring grown-ups back to theaters.
content: The helicopter had the star’s name painted on it, the letters coming into focus as it landed on the retired aircraft carrier, which was adorned for the occasion with an expansive red carpet and a smattering of fighter jets. Tom Cruise. Top Gun. Maverick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Pentagon Taps Next Commander of U.S. Forces in Africa
description: If approved, Lt. Gen. Michael E. Langley would become the first Black four-star Marine Corps officer.
content: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has recommended that the White House promote Lt. Gen. Michael E. Langley of the Marine Corps to be the next head of the military’s Africa Command, two U.S. officials said, in what would be a pathbreaking assignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Cyber Hell’ Review: When Chat Rooms Become Sites of Exploitation
description: This true-crime documentary, subtitled “Exposing an Internet Horror,” recounts a South Korean case in which chat room operators blackmailed young women into sending explicit videos.
content: A true-crime yarn replete with staged re-enactments, “Cyber Hell: Exposing an Internet Horror” joins a growing subgenre of streaming documentaries depicting nightmares of the digital realm. Only this time, the central offense is not cryptocurrency fraud or a dating hoax but a series of sex crimes, including the trade of child sexual abuse imagery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell and Madeleine Ngo
title: Baby Formula Shortage Has an Aggravating Factor: Few Producers
description: With just a handful of companies making U.S. infant formula, a shutdown of Abbott’s plant had outsized impact on the supply.
content: In the early 1990s, the nation’s biggest makers of baby formula were under fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: A Russian rock singer was charged after condemning the Ukraine war at a concert.
description: The singer made the comments less than three months after Russia enacted a law that would punish spreading “false information” about its invasion.
content: A Russian rock musician who condemned the invasion of Ukraine at a concert on Wednesday and questioned why so many Russians and Ukrainians had died was charged with discrediting the army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Your Office, Some Other Guy’s Politics
description: His beliefs, and desk decorations, aren’t really your business, even if they’re in your joint place of work.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bob Neuwirth, Colorful Figure in Dylan’s Circle, Dies at 82
description: He was a recording artist and songwriter himself, but he also played pivotal roles in the careers of Bob Dylan and Janis Joplin.
content: Bob Neuwirth, a painter, recording artist and songwriter who also had an impact as a member of Bob Dylan’s inner circle and as a conduit for two of Janis Joplin’s best-known songs, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: High Wire
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick and Kim Barker
title: A Trooper’s Lethal Force Was Justified by His Boss’s Wife: The Prosecutor
description: A Pennsylvania district attorney is married to the former supervisor of Jay Splain, a state trooper responsible for four deadly shootings over the past 15 years.
content: The district attorney of Lebanon County, Pa., is deciding whether to criminally charge a state trooper who fatally shot a motorist last fall. But the prosecutor, Pier Hess Graf, is unusually close to the case: Her husband, a corporal in the State Police, previously supervised the trooper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Clean Makeup in a Messy World
description: “The idea of wellness has permeated how we think about every aspect of our lives now.” Here are two so-called clean makeup brands on the looks that are trending now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jo Becker and Danny Hakim
title: Ginni Thomas Urged Arizona Lawmakers to Overturn Election
description: The wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas wrote to legislators in a crucial swing state after the Trump campaign’s loss in 2020.
content: In the weeks after the 2020 presidential election, Virginia Thomas, the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, twice lobbied the speaker of the Arizona House and another lawmaker to effectively reverse Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s popular-vote victory and deliver the crucial swing state to Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: A Poet Activist at Brown With a Powerful Voice
description: Amiri Nash charts the Black experience with a new student journal
content: Name: Amiri Nash
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Chun Wai Chan Promoted to Principal Dancer at New York City Ballet
description: Chan, a former principal with Houston Ballet, entered the company as a soloist in 2021 and now becomes its first Chinese principal.
content: New York City Ballet announced on Friday that it was promoting Chun Wai Chan to the role of principal dancer. He will be the company’s first Chinese principal, and just the fourth Asian to hold that rank. Chan, a former principal with Houston Ballet, joined City Ballet as a soloist in August 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Labor Board Seeks Unionization at Starbucks Where Union Lost Election
description: A complaint by the agency accuses the coffee chain of illegally intimidating and retaliating against workers in an election that the union lost.
content: The National Labor Relations Board is seeking to order Starbucks to recognize a union at a Buffalo-area store where the union lost an initial vote last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: ‘You Don’t Pick a Jury. You’re Left With a Jury.’
description: Robin Peguero’s novel, “With Prejudice,” features a tough-talking prosecutor who says, “The jury is a crew of misfits. The scraps that neither side particularly wanted.”
content: The first thing to know before reading Robin Peguero’s WITH PREJUDICE (Grand Central Publishing, 314 pp., $28) is that only six people serve on most criminal case juries in Florida. Those who are accustomed to juries of 12 may be initially thrown off, as I was. I note this because it foreshadows the more exciting ways this debut legal thriller from a former Miami homicide prosecutor (and current congressional investigative counsel) keeps the reader off balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Bernie Sanders Prepares for ‘War’ With AIPAC and Its Super PAC
description: The pro-Israel group, which is involved with direct political spending this year for the first time, has opposed progressive candidates backed by Mr. Sanders.
content: Senator Bernie Sanders, the progressive former presidential candidate who rose to prominence in part by denouncing the influence of wealthy interests in politics, has a new target in his sights: the American Israel Public Affairs Committee and its affiliated super PAC, which is spending heavily in Democratic primaries for the first time this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo, Constant Méheut, Selam Gebrekidan and Catherine Porter
title: How a French Bank Captured Haiti
description: It helped finance the Eiffel Tower as it drained millions from Haiti. The bank, C.I.C., won’t talk about it, but The Times tracked how much its investors made — and what Haiti lost.
content: Every sentence of the invitation ended with an inky flourish, a triple loop of calligraphy befitting a night of dinner, dancing and fireworks at Haiti’s national palace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Constant Méheut, Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
title: The Root of Haiti’s Misery: Reparations to Enslavers
description: In 1791, enslaved Haitians ousted the French and founded a nation. But France made generations of Haitians pay for their freedom. How much it cost them was a mystery, until now.
content: DONDON, Haiti — Adrienne Present steps into the thin forest beside her house and plucks the season’s first coffee cherries, shining like red marbles in her hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Buffalo Mourns ‘Star in the Midst of Turmoil’ Killed in Racist Attack
description: Heyward Patterson, a 67-year-old church deacon whose life revolved around service and faith, was the first of 10 massacre victims to be laid to rest.
content: BUFFALO — Amy Pilc never socialized with Heyward Patterson, a jitney driver at the grocery store where she often shopped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Christopher Mele
title: Tornado in Northern Michigan Kills One and Injures More Than 40
description: Numerous homes and businesses were damaged in Gaylord, a city of about 4,000, officials said.
content: At least one person was killed and 44 people were injured when a tornado swept through Northern Michigan on Friday, damaging numerous homes and businesses, flipping cars and downing trees, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Roger Angell, Who Wrote About Baseball With Passion, Dies at 101
description: In elegantly winding articles for The New Yorker loaded with inventive imagery, he wrote more like a fan than a sports journalist.
content: Roger Angell, the elegant and thoughtful baseball writer who was widely considered among the best America has produced, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Is Stagflation Making a Comeback?
description: It depends on how you define the s-word.
content: When I talk to business groups these days, the most commonly asked question is, “Are we headed for stagflation?” I’m pretty sure they find my response unsatisfying, because I tell them it depends on their definition of the term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Despite a landmark toll from Covid, there is still no U.S. memorial to the dead.
description: As the United States reached 1 million known deaths, there was no national, permanent memorial to the country’s loss. Some survivors have called for more to be done.
content: Minutes before a crowd of lawmakers gathered on the steps of the Capitol last week to mark the impending U.S. death toll of 1 million from Covid, it began to rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Justin Thomas Has Something to Prove, and a Chance to Prove It
description: He’ll have to get past several rising young players to win his second major title. Tiger Woods made the cut at the P.G.A. Championship but is a dozen strokes off the lead.
content: TULSA, Okla. — Much of the late second-round drama on Friday at the 2022 P.G.A. Championship involved Tiger Woods’s desperate quest to remain in the tournament. In the end, a limping Woods rallied to make the event’s halfway cut by shooting a one-under-par 69 that left him tied for 53rd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: The Humiliation of Amber Heard Is Both Modern and Medieval
description: Whatever you think of the actress, what we are watching is a good old-fashioned public pillorying — only difference is that memes have replaced the stones.
content: There was a moment in a Virginia courtroom this month when the actress Amber Heard paused mid-sniffle on the stand. She was testifying about abuse she says she suffered at the hands of her movie star ex-husband, Johnny Depp, when she wiped her nose with a tissue — then seemed to freeze as her face was illuminated by a flash, as if she were instinctively posing for a photo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Starting a Life Together Where Others Are Laid to Rest
description: Hannah Margaret Allen and Grant Schumacher chose to marry at her family’s funeral home, where “there’s a lot of life and energy,” said the groom.
content: When Hannah Margaret Allen and Grant Joseph Schumacher met for drinks on June 7, 2019, it was his first time going on a date with someone he had met online. Ms. Allen, by her approximation, had done so 50 times by then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: U.S. Company Supplying Russian Military Seeks Exit, Caught Between Sanctions and Kremlin
description: Arconic runs a huge Russian metal plant, bought in an era of cooperation between the U.S. and Russia. Now it is struggling, after years of increasing Russian military aggression.
content: The Samara Metallurgical Plant, a sprawling complex in southwestern Russia that spans an area the size of a dozen city blocks, is a cornerstone of Russian industry. It is the country’s largest supplier of aluminum commercial and industrial products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: What Is Monkeypox?
description: There have been dozens of cases reported in recent weeks among populations not typically vulnerable to the disease.
content: The rare monkeypox virus, usually confined mostly to Central and West Africa, has spread in unusual ways this year, and among populations that have not been vulnerable in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia’s Election: What to Watch and What’s at Stake
description: While voters are most focused on cost-of-living issues, the opposition Labor Party has made the election a referendum on the conduct of Prime Minister Scott Morrison.
content: Australians go to the polls on Saturday to choose a government as the country, emerging from two years of Covid-fueled isolation, faces rising inflation, persistent anxiety about climate change and growing foreign policy challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Big Tech Is Getting Clobbered on Wall Street. It’s a Good Time for Them.
description: Flush with cash, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Google are positioned to emerge from a downturn stronger and more powerful. As usual.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and the parent companies of Facebook and Google have lost $2.7 trillion in value so far this year, about the annual gross domestic product of Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Marcus Smart Is Delivering Exactly What the Celtics Need
description: Smart, the Celtics’ point guard, made an impact on offense and defense as Boston beat Miami in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals.
content: Boston Celtics guard Marcus Smart had an open lane for an easy fast-break basket. Then he unnecessarily moved the ball behind his back and flubbed a layup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway theaters will continue requiring patrons to wear masks at least through June 30.
description: The decision comes at a time when New York City has declared a “high Covid alert.”
content: Broadway theaters will continue to require ticketholders to wear masks at least through June 30, industry leaders said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: With the Volt Festival, the Playwright Karen Hartman Comes Home
description: 59E59 Theaters is putting a spotlight on a midcareer artist whose work has seldom been seen locally.
content: “I’m feeling a tremendous sense of visibility,” the playwright Karen Hartman said. “And it’s not when I expected to be visible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Chaos in Israel Gives New Chance to Old Face: Benjamin Netanyahu
description: Mr. Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, lost office last summer. Now the coalition that replaced him is crumbling — potentially leading to new elections that could return him to power.
content: CAIRO — A potentially devastating defection from Israel’s fragile governing coalition this week has thrown a political lifeline to Benjamin Netanyahu, the country’s longest-serving prime minister, who lost office last June when the current government was formed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Dana Rubinstein
title: De Blasio Will Run for Congress in Newly Drawn District
description: Bill de Blasio, the ex-mayor of New York City, said on Friday that he would run for the House of Representatives in a new district that includes parts of Brooklyn and Manhattan.
content: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, announced on Friday that he would run for Congress in a newly created district stretching from Lower Manhattan to his home in Brooklyn, testing a political return in an already crowded Democratic primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: A Roger Angell Reader
description: A look back at some of The New Yorker writer and editor’s most beloved books.
content: Roger Angell, who died at 101 on May 20, 2022, was best known for his books about baseball — most of them essay collections, as clean and sharp as a perfectly batted line drive. But he also wrote humorous articles, parodies and autobiographical pieces, many of which were collected elsewhere. If you want to read some of his work, any of these books would be a fine place to start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Even Among Corporate Raiders, Elon Musk Is a Pirate
description: The world of deal making has always been rough and tumble. But Mr. Musk blows any predecessors away.
content: The history of mergers and acquisitions is filled with ruthless corporate raiders, bruising wars of words and people trying to stiff each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Step by Step, Embracing a Future With Each Other
description: Doug Lockwood and Linda Murphy met in 2019 as members of a support group for people who had lost longtime spouses. A year later came a series of walks that eventually led them to the altar.
content: Douglas Alan Lockwood can pinpoint the exact moment something shifted in his perception of Linda Marie Cadranel Murphy. It was July 2020 and, apropos of the times, they were in a Zoom meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Williams
title: In Milan, an Iconic Stadium Isn’t Going Down Without a Fight
description: The soccer teams that share the San Siro, which has hosted two World Cups and four European finals, want to replace it with a more modern arena. Not everyone is ready to see it go.
content: As he watched the soccer game playing out on television, the Milanese writer and actor Gianfelice Facchetti felt an emotional tug that he thought might be leading him toward his next book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Lawyer Says He Dealt Directly With Trump Over Jan. 6 Plans
description: John Eastman said in a court filing that he had received handwritten notes from President Donald J. Trump as they strategized about how to keep him in power.
content: WASHINGTON — The conservative lawyer John Eastman, the architect of a strategy to overturn the 2020 election, dealt directly with President Donald J. Trump and received handwritten notes from him as the men sought to keep Mr. Trump in power, according to a new court filing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Schwartz
title: Piecing Together the Messages of Elon Musk
description: A New York Times Presents documentary team had to assemble a visionary’s vision without his participation.
content: One of the first things you hear when talking with people who’ve worked with Elon Musk, even those who have worked with him for years, is that you never really know what he’s thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Summer Lee, a progressive Democrat, wins the primary for a House seat in Pennsylvania.
description: Ms. Lee, who could become the first Black woman to represent Pennsylvania in Congress, won an expensive and fiercely fought primary battle after days of vote-counting.
content: PITTSBURGH — State Representative Summer Lee, a progressive Democrat who could become the first Black woman to represent Pennsylvania in Congress, won an expensive and fiercely fought primary battle on Friday after three days of vote-counting, defeating a more centrist contender who was the favorite of the party establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Cannes 2022: How Jessica Chastain Played Donald Trump’s Sister
description: The director James Gray based the cameo on an actual incident from his childhood, but filling the role proved quite a challenge.
content: There’s nothing like a big cameo in the second half of a movie to make a wilted festival audience sit back up in their seats. On Friday at the Cannes Film Festival, I watched “EO,” an art film about a Polish donkey that somehow, in its final act, makes room for a psychosexual cameo from a cutlery-tossing Isabelle Huppert. (When it comes to cinematic jolts, Huppert provided a most welcome espresso shot.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Bodies Pulled From Parched Lake Mead Stir Wise-Guy Ghosts of Las Vegas
description: As climate change fuels grim discoveries across the West, Las Vegas is awash in bets on the identity of a suspected murder victim dumped in a barrel.
content: LAS VEGAS — It’s the mob guy who went missing after skimming from the Stardust casino. No, it’s the lake resort manager hunted down by the Chicago Outfit. Could it be the work of a biker gang muscling in on Mafia turf? Or maybe someone just fell off a boat after one too many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘Stranger Things’ Is Back, and the Duffer Brothers Made It Big
description: After a three-year wait, the new season of Netflix’s sci-fi series is more ambitious (and longer) than ever. The creators say it’s all part of the plan.
